docs.abstract: Thanks for the flattering commercials, but we’re about to lose our hazard pay.
docs.snippet: Thanks for the flattering commercials, but we’re about to lose our hazard pay.
docs.lead_paragraph: While Amazon may glorify its workers with sentimental commercials, thanking them for their heroic bravery, it has also rolled back some policies designed to keep those very workers safe during this pandemic. And on June 1, it’s getting rid of hazard pay too, even though its facilities continue to see outbreaks of the coronavirus.

headline.main: We Work in an Amazon Warehouse. We Didn’t Sign Up to Be Heroes.

byline.original: By Courtenay Brown and Jordan Flowers

docs.abstract: Communicating with loved ones is crucial to get through quarantine, and it doesn’t have to be complicated.
docs.snippet: Communicating with loved ones is crucial to get through quarantine, and it doesn’t have to be complicated.
docs.lead_paragraph: For most of us, the coronavirus pandemic moved our lives almost entirely inside and online. Staying in touch with loved ones near and far away now relies on a patchwork of phone calls, emails, text messages and an array of video-chat platforms.

headline.main: 5 Ways to Stay in Touch With Less Tech-Savvy Family and Friends

byline.original: By Grant Clauser and Ben Keough

docs.abstract: It won’t be Amazon or the coronavirus. It will be artificially high rents.
docs.snippet: It won’t be Amazon or the coronavirus. It will be artificially high rents.
docs.lead_paragraph: Every weekday I drive to my four bookstores, pick up our customers’ orders, wedge them into the back of my car and take them to the Cooper Station post office. My route takes me to Williamsburg to Downtown Brooklyn to the South Street Seaport, and ends at my original store in NoLIta.

headline.main: What Could Kill My New York Bookstores?

docs.abstract: Amazon and other companies are planning to test workers for the coronavirus. But there is little federal guidance, and some fear it could lead to a false sense of security.
docs.snippet: Amazon and other companies are planning to test workers for the coronavirus. But there is little federal guidance, and some fear it could lead to a false sense of security.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the country reopens, employers are looking into how to safely bring back their workers. One recurring question: Should they be tested for the new coronavirus?

headline.main: What Role Should Employers Play in Testing Workers?
headline.print_headline: Employers Get Little Direction Over Staff Tests

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

byline.original: By Steve Eder, Ellen Gabler, Sarah Kliff and Heather Murphy

docs.abstract: After losing some online shoppers to rivals during the pandemic, the retail giant is turning back to faster shipping times and big sales.
docs.snippet: After losing some online shoppers to rivals during the pandemic, the retail giant is turning back to faster shipping times and big sales.
docs.lead_paragraph: As millions more Americans turned to online shopping during the pandemic, Amazon struggled to keep up with the demand, and its rivals pounced. Target’s online sales shot up 141 percent last quarter, while Walmart’s rose 74 percent. Etsy’s were up almost 80 percent in April.

headline.main: Amazon Angles to Grab Back Customers
headline.print_headline: Amazon Lets Off the Brake Amid a Surge By Its Rivals

docs.abstract: Lawmakers want to question Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, as part of its antitrust investigation.
docs.snippet: Lawmakers want to question Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, as part of its antitrust investigation.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee on Friday called on Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, to testify before Congress, in a major escalation of its investigation into the country’s largest technology companies.

headline.main: Congress Calls on Jeff Bezos of Amazon to Testify
headline.print_headline: Congress Seeks Bezos Testimony, Adding to Scrutiny of Tech Giants

docs.abstract: The company said it would be happy to send someone to testify. But it never mentions Jeff Bezos.
docs.snippet: The company said it would be happy to send someone to testify. But it never mentions Jeff Bezos.
docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon responded to lawmakers on Friday who demanded that its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, testify as part of a congressional antitrust investigation.

headline.main: Amazon Makes No Promises on Bezos Testimony
headline.print_headline: Washington: Amazon Is Noncommittal On Bezos Testimony

docs.abstract: The best shopping ideas now are coming from big box stores. Where are Amazon’s innovations?
docs.snippet: The best shopping ideas now are coming from big box stores. Where are Amazon’s innovations?
docs.lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

docs.abstract: The director Andrew Patterson discusses a sequence from his film, now streaming on Amazon Prime.
docs.snippet: The director Andrew Patterson discusses a sequence from his film, now streaming on Amazon Prime.
docs.lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline.main: How ‘The Vast of Night’ Builds Tension With a Strange Sound

docs.abstract: The pandemic briefly brought the Everything Store to its knees — by prematurely bringing about a future it has long been planning for.
docs.snippet: The pandemic briefly brought the Everything Store to its knees — by prematurely bringing about a future it has long been planning for.
docs.lead_paragraph: The pandemic briefly brought the Everything Store to its knees — by prematurely bringing about a future it has long been planning for.
